VLIB Function Reference

Uniformly-Weighted Running Variance of a Video

Introduction and Use Cases

A background subtraction algorithm might consist of:
  1. Computing a representative statistic of the luma component for each pixel in a video.
  2. Labeling deviations from this statistic as foreground. The uniformly-weighted running variance of a pixel can be used in deciding whether an observed deviation is statistically significant.

Specification

Function

Updates the (uniformly-weighted) running variance of the luma component of a video. If the foreground mask bit of either the newest or the oldest video frame is set, indicating there is obstruction by a foreground object, the running variance will not be updated.

Inputs


    *updatedVar             Updated running variance buffer       (SQ12.3)
    *previousVar            Previous running variance buffer      (SQ12.3)
    *updatedMean            Updated running mean buffer           (SQ8.7)
    *previousMean           Previous running mean buffer          (SQ8.7)
    *newestData             Most recent luma buffer               (SQ8.0)
    *newestMask32packed     Newest foreground mask                (32-bit packed)
    *oldestMask32packed     Oldest foreground mask                (32-bit packed)
     pixelCount             Number of pixels to process           (UQ32.0)
     frameCount             Number of frames in video buffer      (UQ8.0)

Outputs

    Returns VLIB Error Status

Method

In the implementation shown in the following equation, the running variance is updated for those pixels where the foreground mask of the oldest and newest frames are zero: 
    updatedVar = 1 / (frameCount - 1) x (frameCount x previousVar + (newestData - updatedMean) x (newestData - previousMean))

APIS

  • VLIB_updateUWRVarianceS16
  • VLIB_initMeanWithLumaS16
  • VLIB_initVarWithConstS16

Notes

  • I/O buffers are assumed to be double-word aligned in memory.
  • pixelCount must be a multiple of 8.
